q: How do I impress my professor?
a: Submit assignments on time. That’s more magical than flowers.

q: How can I stay awake in class?
a: Sit in the front row. Fear is better than caffeine.
Write things down. Your brain is not a reliable hard drive during 8am lectures.

q: How to make friends in college?
a: Share notes, share snacks, share memes. In that order.
Pick the one with fewer assignments and better Wi-Fi. Follow your heart… and timetable.

q: How to deal with a strict professor?
a: Read the rubric. It’s basically the cheat codes they gave you for free.
Plan like a CEO, execute like a student: start early, finish before panic mode.
Pomodoro: 25 mins focus, 5 mins scrolling—uh, stretching. Repeat.
Assign roles on day one. Otherwise you’ll all be ‘documentation person’ at 2am.
Past papers + active recall. Guessing the pattern is half the syllabus.
Don’t. Just ask good questions and don’t call them ‘sir/ma’am’ every sentence.
Projects on GitHub, a clean resume, and LinkedIn stalking—but the professional kind.

q: What to do if I missed a lecture?
a: Ask a classmate for notes. Bribe with chocolate if necessary.
Only as important as passing. Do the math for your college’s rules.
Make a two-week rescue plan. One topic per day, no hero speeches.
Start an easy task. Momentum beats motivation every time.
Teach a friend. If they get it, you’ll remember it. If not, you’ll both cry.

q: How to talk to a professor?
a: Be concise, be polite, include your roll number. Professors love organized students.

q: How to balance coding and classes?
a: Timebox coding sprints. Don’t debug your life at 3am before lab viva.

q: How to make a good resume?
a: One page, measurable impact, links that actually work. No ‘MS Paint - Expert’ please.

q: How to pick a project idea?
a: Find a daily annoyance and automate it. Boom—innovation.

q: How to handle results day stress?
a: Deep breaths. Your CGPA is a number, not a prophecy.
High-yield topics first. Don’t start a Netflix series called ‘Entire Syllabus’.
Only if you like remembering things tomorrow.

q: How to ask doubts in class?
a: Ask. Half the class has the same doubt; the other half is on mute.
Practice the common programs until your fingers type them on autopilot.
Attend one meeting. If they give you free stickers, you’ve found your people.
Talk to seniors after events. Ask for one tip, not their entire life story.

q: What to do if I fail an exam?
a: Regroup, plan a retake strategy, and avoid the ‘I’ll study tomorrow’ trap.
Be honest: ‘I don’t know yet—but here’s how I’d find out.’ That line saves lives.

q: How to save money in college?
a: Learn the sacred art of canteen combos and split subscriptions.

q: How to pick a laptop for college?
a: Battery, keyboard, RAM. Looks are a bonus; not a degree.
Tiny wins daily. Big dreams are built from boring Tuesdays.
Move your body, touch sunlight, drink water. Free therapy pack.
Big fonts, fewer words, one message per slide. No essays on slides, please.
